choices.text: Most common cause of esophageal perforation is Boerhaave's Syndrome
Iatrogenic perforation is most common in cervical esophagus
May cause pneumomediastinum and surgical emphysema
Prompt surgical repair should be done in all cases of Boerhaave's Syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about esophageal perforation is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Most common cause of esophageal perforation is Iatrogenic

•	Boerhaave syndrome is a spontaneous transmural perforation of the esophagus resulting from a sudden rise in intraluminal pressure caused by an uncoordinated act of forceful vomiting against a closed cricopharyngeal sphincter. 

•	More than 90% of these perforations occur in the left posterolateral wall of the lower third of the esophagus. 

•	The Mackler triad seen in Boerhaave syndrome comprises of:

1.	Vomiting

2.	Lower chest pain

3.	Subcutaneous emphysema (50%)

 •	Hamman's sign (Hammond's sign or Hammond's crunch) is a crunching, rasping sound, synchronous with the heartbeat, heard over the precordium in spontaneous mediastinal emphysema produced by the heart beating against air-filled tissues. 

• Treatment: Early detection and surgical repair within the first 24 hours results in 80% to 90% survival; after 24 hours, survival decreases to less than 50%.

questions.text: A 50 year old patient complains of haematemesis after retching and vomiting following a night of binge drinking. Upper GI endoscopy reveals a mucosal tear just below the gastroesophageal junction which is not actively bleeding. Which of the following is MOST appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:

Mallory Weiss tear without active bleeding is managed conservatively

questions.text: A young female presented with dysphagia more for liquids. Barium picture is given below. What is the gold standard test for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Achalasia Cardia

•	Due to absence of Inhibitory Auerbach’s plexus

•	Secondary achalasia – due to Chagas disease

•	Psudoachalasia: Due to cancer (Cardia > lung)

•	Young age/ Dysphagia - Liquids > solid

•	Increased risk of SCC (In proximal dilated part)

•	X ray- Bird beak sign/ rat tail sign/ sigmoidisation 

•	Manometry – Gold standard (Chicago classification)

•	TOC- Hellers myotomy and Dor (partial fundoplication)

•	POEM (New treatment)

questions.text: A full-term male newborn experiences respiratory distress immediately after birth. A prenatal sonogram had been read as normal. An emergency radiograph is shown below. The patient was intubated and placed on 100% O2. The arterial blood gas revealed pH 7.24; PO2 60 kPa; PCO2 52 kPa. The baby has sternal retractions and a scaphoid abdomen. Which of the following statements correctly refers to this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This is a case of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (Left posterolateral- Bochdalek). It is due to persistence of pleuroperitoneal canal. Size of defect and early surgery do not affect prognosis.

questions.text: A 5 week old male child presents with projectile non- Bilious vomiting, his X ray image is given below. What is the electrolyte imbalance seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

CONGENITAL HYPERTROPHIC PYLORIC STENOSIS

•	Results in hypertrophy and hyperplasia of Circular muscle.

•	Erythromycin given within 1 week after birth increases the risk of CHPS  

•	Results in gastric outflow obstruction, vomiting and dehydration 

•	Affects 3 per 1000 live births 

•	Male : female 4:1. Most common in first born males 

•	Usually presents between 4 and 6 weeks (3-8) of age 

•	Child hungry and often feeds immediately after vomiting 

•	Biochemically a hypochloraemic alkalosis exists (with hypokalemia and paradoxical aciduria)

•	Non-bilious vomiting, associated with weight loss and dehydration, are typical. 

•	The upper abdomen may be distended with visible gastric peristalsis (left to right) and a palpable olive shaped lump (hypertrophied pylorus). 

•	Features of protein energy malneutrition is absent

•	Confirmation of the diagnosis is by ultrasound scanning. – Length of pylorus > 16 mm, width >  4 mm has a accuracy of > 95%. 

Stomach is empty doesn’t have food residue.

•	First electrolyte imbalance correction is must by – N/2 NS {(.45% saline) with 5% dextrose and Kcl} or RL (RL may increase alakalosis)

•	At laparotomy, pyloromyotomy (Ramstedt's operation) is the usual procedure done through right hypochondrial transverse muscle splitting incision. 

•	Atropine is medical management (Not preferred)

questions.text: Which type of gastric ulcer is associated with increased gastric acid secretion.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Type II

choices.text: According to Borrmann's classification, Linitis plastica is type IV
Early gastric cancer is defined by a cancer involving mucosa, submucosa irrespective of lymph nodes

questions.text: False about GIST:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

•	2- 3% of gastric cancer

•	GIST arises from intretstitial cell of Cajal, autonomic nerve–related GI pacemaker cells (mesenchymal components) from Muscularis propria.

•	Most common sites: Stomach (50-60%)> Small Intestine, ileum (25%) > Rectum/ Esophagus.

•	Most are positive for CD117 (>90%), CD 34 (>70%), BCL 2.

•	5% associated with plate derived growth factor alpha- 5% (PDGF α has good prognosis)

•	Other tumor markers are DOG1 and protein kinase C theta.

•	Two types: Spindle cell (70% most common), epitheloid (30%) and rarely pleomorphic.

•	Age of presentation after 4th decade, usually around 60 years.

•	Main presenting symptom: Bleeding (75%) > Pain and dyspepsia. Mass  in 60%

Malignant potential is decided by:

1: Size > 5 cm

2: metastasis: Vascular or peritoneal (Lymphatic involvement is very rare- 5%-10%)

3: Mitotic Index: > 5 / 50 HPF  

4: Cellular atypia, necrosis, or local invasion. 

5: c-kit mutations occur predominantly in malignant GISTs and are an unfavorable prognostic marker. Most c-kit mutations occur in exon 11 and result in activation of c-kit. 
 
Investigation: 

•	CECT: for primary tumour

•	PET: For secondary.

Treatment: Surgical resection (segmental with 1 cm margin)

Node involvement is very rare (so lymphadenectomy is not usually required).

•	Imatinib mesylate (selective inhibitor of type 3 tyrosine kinase KIT) is best adjuvant therapy. Used in CD117 positive unrespectable tumour or metastatic GIST.

•	PET is best investigation to assess response of Imatinib

•	Sunitinib is used in Imatinib resistance cases.

•	This tumor is radio resistant

Tumour size is predominant factor for survival.

Most common site of disease failure in Liver

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of pyogenic liver abscess?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Most common cause of pyogenic liver abscess is ascending infection from biliary tract due to a distal obstruction. Most common cause of a distal obstruction is stones, but it can also occur because of cholangiocarcinoma. Option A is wrong as trauma can be a cause of a pyogenic liver abscess but it is not the most common cause Colonic diverticulosis and ruptured appendicitis are the other causes of pyogenic liver abscess but they are not the most common cause.

questions.text: Best treatment for a patient who presents with Reynolds pentad is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Patient is suffering from cholangitis and choledocholithiasis and should be managed by ERCP followed by laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
IV antibiotics and aggressive hydration are the initial treatment in patients with acute cholangitis. Biliary decompression may be performed endoscopically or by a percutaneous transhepatic route based on the level of the obstruction. 

Patients with acute cholangitis should be treated with systemic antibiotics and other supportive measures this usually controls the attack within 24–48 hours. If the patient's condition worsens or if marked improvement is not observed within 2–4 days, endoscopic sphincterotomy or surgery and common bile duct exploration should be performed.

choices.text: Cholecystectomy with resection of the extrahepatic biliary tract and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and jaundice. Subsequent “MRCP” reveals a cystic anomaly of her biliary system illustrated in the film shown here. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

This is type I choledochal cyst which is the commonest type (>85%)

Five major types are (Todani):

•	Type I cysts are the most common and represent 80-90% of choledochal cysts. They consist of saccular or fusiform dilatations of the common bile duct, which involve either a segment of the duct or the entire duct. 

•	Type II choledochal cysts appear as an isolated diverticulum protruding from the wall of the common bile duct. 

•	Type III choledochal cysts arise from the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct (choledochocele).

questions.text: In Strasberg classiﬁcation bile duct injury, transection of rt sectoral duct is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Type C

questions.text: 2.5 years Post cholecystectomy patients comes with CBD stone? What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

A "retained CBD stone" refers to a gallstone that was missed during a procedure to remove stones from the common bile duct (CBD), essentially a stone that was left behind, while a "recurrent CBD stone" is a new stone that forms in the CBD after an initial procedure to remove stones, meaning it developed sometime after the initial treatment.

Retained is found within 2 years and recurrent is found after 2 years.

Recurrent stone is primary stone and usually made up of brown pigment stone.

choices.text: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy with Port site excision

questions.text: What is best treatment for GB cancer involving muscle of GB is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Treatment

•	Simple cholecystectomy for Tis and T1a lesions 

•	Extended (radical cholecystectomy) for T1b lesions and T2 tumors- Cholecystectomy with 1 cm adjoining tissue of liver or “en bloc” resection of the liver bed (Couinaud segments 4B and 5).

•	T3 tumors perforate the serosa and/or directly invade adjacent organs so they are treated by radical resection of the involved organ.

•	T4 tumors are usually not amenable to surgical resection

•	lymphadenectomy is advocated in GBC as a staging procedure not for survival.

•	If the cystic duct margin is positive, then bile duct excision and Roux en y reconstruction should be done.

•	The benefit of excision of Port Site Resection is not supported by data.

•	The role of adjuvant radiotherapy or chemoradiotherapy has been poor. 

•	Gemcitabine and cisplatin or 5 FU is used a adjuvant therapy.

choices.text: It may be found anywhere from mediastinum to scrotum.
Most common site is lesser sac
Any cyst located below transverse mesocolon is best treated by cystojejunostomy
Pseudocyst develops only after 4 weeks due to epithelization of the wall.

questions.text: False statement about pseudopancreatic cyst is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pseudocyst in not lined by epithelium. It is only lined by granulation tissue.

Pseudocyst of pancreas is fibrosed walling off of peripancreatic fluid collection. It takes place only after 4 weeks. It is lined by Granulataion tissue (No epithelial lining)

About >85% are present in lesser sac but it may be found anywhere in retroperitoneum. It may extent into mediastinum or into scrotum. 
Cystogastrostomy (Jurasz) procedure is preferred treatment for psudopancreatic cyst when it is situated in lesser sac.. It is done after 6 weeks and when size is more than 5 cm.

For low lying pseudocyst (extending below transeverse mesocolon, cystojejunostomy is a preferred procedure).

80% patients of acute pancreatitis respond to conservative treatment.

questions.text: A 10-months old infant presents with acute intestinal obstruction. Contrast enema X-ray shows claw sign. Most likely etiology is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Intussusception

Claw Sign

•    Peak incidence age -  6 month- 1 year (Weaning)

•    Frequently occurs infection Adenovirus type 3 virus (lymphoid hyperplasia that act as “lead point” (of Peyer's patch- MCQ).

•    Rota virus vaccine (MCQ)/ Meckel’s ectopic tissue/ Lymphoma/ Adenoma or polyp/ HS

•    Presentation-

•    Colicky abdominal pain/ Red currant jelly stool/ Empty right iliac fossa- Dance sign/ Sausage or Banana shaped lump in epigastrium  (with concavity towards umbilicus).

questions.text: False statement about Meconium peritonitis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Meconium Ileus (MI) is the earliest clinical manifestation of Cystic fibrosis (seen in 10-15% of CF2).

•	Meconium is viscid having high protein and low carbohydrate content causing antenatal or post natal obstruction. 

•	The most common presentation is abdominal distension with or without bilious vomiting and a failure or delay in passing meconium 
after birth. 

•	Occasionally it is diagnosed prenatally on ultrasound scans.

•	Complicated MI includes those with volvulus, atresia, perforation or giant cystic peritonitis. Abdominal x-ray is likely to show several loops of dilated small bowel without air-fluid levels; and possibly a soap bubble appearance in the right lower quadrant, the so-called Neuhauser sign. Perforation or giant cystic meconium peritonitis calcifications are often noted. Most babies then undergo barium enema to confirm the diagnosis. 

•	Gastrograffin enemas (GGE) in the treatment of simple MI. All neonates with complicated and those with 2 unsuccessful GGE require operative intervention.

•	The surgical management options of MI are varied and include : 

1) Enterotomy/appendicectomy with irrigation 

2) Enterostomy with/out resection

3) Resection with primary anastomosis

•	Treatment of choice is Bishop-Koop (End-to-distal side ileal anastomosis with a distal end ileostomy which allows post-operative irrigation of the meconium pellets)

questions.text: Kalloo, 25yrs, presented with a mass in the right iliac fossa. On laparotomy it was found to be a carcinoid 2.5cms in diameter in appendix. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Right hemicolectomy 

Carcinoid tumours occur most often in the ileum and appendix, and are usually chance findings at appendicectomy. The tumour arise from the argentaffin of Kulchitzky cells which lie deep in the crypts of Lieberkühn and are derived from neural crest tissue. Like other APUD tumours, carcinoids contain numerous neurosecretory granules. 

Large tumours may cause obstruction or intussusception, but symptoms are otherwise rare unless metastases to the liver are responsible for the carcinoid syndrome (seen only in 1% of cases). This syndrome is due to the excessive production of a variety of gut hormones - particularly 5-hydroxytryptamine, but also histamine, kinins, catecholamines, and prostaglandins. 

Typically, patients present with episodic facial flushing, watery diarrhoea, and abdominal cramps (due to serotonin), and may have pellagra-like skin lesions as a result of niacin deficiency. Involvement of the right side of the heart is also well recognized (TR> TS> PS), and there may be bronchial lesions. Auscultation may indicate pulmonary and/or tricuspid valve lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of massive small bowel resection (Short bowel syndrome)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Gall stones (Pigment type)

SHORT BOWEL SYNDROME

• Main causes: Mesenteric Ischemia/ Midgut volvulus/ Traumatic SMA tear.

• Humans can tolerate 25% of resection of small bowel without ileo-caecal junction.

• In children < 45 Cm and in adults < 60 cm with ICJ is not compatible with life

• Length of SI less than 200 cm lads to Malabsorption (Short bowel syndrome)

• Proximal bowel resection is better tolerated than distal. Ileum can take over function of jejunum but not vice-versa.

• Intestinal adaption- Hyperplasia of cell, Increase in length of villi

• Hypergastrenemia occurs

• Presentation of SB syndrome:

• Diarrhoea, Steatorrhoea, Malabsorption, Gall stones (cholesterol) and Vit B 12 def Anaemia and oxalate renal stones.

•	Only seen in males, Type I is most common, Valve is present just below Veru montanum

•	Associated features are- Oligohydromnios, Renal dysplasia, Bladder dysfunction, Pulmonary hypoplasia (M/C cause of death)

•	MCU is IOC. 

USG shows key hole sign (Prenatal diagnosis can be made on USG after 28 weeks)

•	Endoscopic fulguration is treatment of choice

In deranged renal function or urinary ascites Vasicostomy is best (Blockson’s technique)

questions.text: "HIVEC" is a newer technique used in the treatment of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hyperthermic intravesical chemotherapy (HIVEC) is a treatment for non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC). It involves heating the bladder to 42–43 °C while delivering chemotherapy drugs directly into the bladder. 

Mainly used for patients who are unfit for radical cystectomy or those are who are BCG-unresponsive or have contra-indications for BCG
In HIVEC® treatment 40mg Mitomycin C is instilled in bladder for 60 minutes at 43°C ±0.5°C in weekly installations for six weeks, followed by monthly installations for six months.
